data.text: GT Grade Carbon Elite: A Good Idea?
This bike GT Grade carbon elite it would be my first carbon bike, is it a good idea? I feel like i'm getting a alot of mixed information on its durability from googling it

Those seatstays have "vertical compliance with lateral stiffness" written all over them. But it looks like a decent bike, with the signature GT seatstays-toptube triangle. If you are doubtful, buy a bike with a steel frame I guess? This one looks just fine, though.
data.author: Mark Thorrowgood

data.text: Carbon bikes are being beaten to a pulp on a daily basis worldwide without catastrophic failure left and right. The ancient credo that carbon is somehow less durable than aluminium is a myth. I have seen more broken aluminium frames in my life than carbon frames. If you do want something for life go Ti. Steel is grossly overrated.
data.author: Xaver von Treyer

data.text: I‚Äôve seen quite a few failed welds on ti bikes from nearly every manufacturer. ‚ÄúTi is forever‚Äú is also a myth
data.author: Jeff Bollinger

data.text: Fair point.
data.author: Xaver von Treyer

data.text: Do you have any statistics or are your observations anecdotal? Nothing is 100% bulletproof, but I believe that Ti has the best overall durability from my anecdotal observations. The weakness in carbon in general is with impacts
data.author: Young Jun Son

data.text: Cough, Giant, cough üòÇüòÇ

data.text: I don‚Äôt think steel is overrated but rather the whole ‚Äústeel is real‚Äù movement has made many grossly overpriced.
data.author: Ryan Lane

data.text: Ti is amazing, doesn‚Äôt fatigue along with several other positive merits. I‚Äôd love one but I‚Äôm not paying the price of 5-10 non-ti frames to get one. Really all materials are costing way much more than they should these days.
data.author: Ryan Lane

data.text: yes, if you're talking Moots, Mosaic, Seven, Firefly - yes, super pricey. But American brands Lynskey and Litespeed are close to carbon prices ($1500-2000ish). And if you're OK with an Asian-made frame - those are super affordable. T-Lab, Dean, and Sage are also less than the super expensive brands.
data.author: Young Jun Son

data.text: I‚Äôve looked into Lynskey a few times, might give one of them a go one day.
data.author: Ryan Lane

data.text: Yes. It will be a great option.
data.author: Larry Dyer

data.text: That bike has good components and the frame is likely made in the same facility as many of the other name brands. At that price point, you'll be hard pressed to do much better. Barring substantial abuse outside of intended gravel riding, it will last a long time. Note: I ride my carbon gravel bikes on rocky MTB single track all the time with no problems.

data.text: yeah i'm getting 500 usd off it aswell, so I think i'm gonna jump on it. I'm just suprised it isn't selling with a gravel bike shortage in my country

data.author: Magn√∫s Bjartur Solveigarson

data.text: The thing that pushes some away from carbon is not that it fails more often or more easily than other materials. The thing is, that when it fails, it often fails suddenly and spectacularly‚Ä¶. With little or no warning.
data.author: Harold Huard

data.text: yeah, carbon fiber is always failing. That‚Äôs why we make F16‚Äôs and space shuttles with it.
data.author: John Simon

data.text: I didn‚Äôt say it failed at any higher rate. I said it‚Äôs known to fail suddenly when it does. Oh‚Ä¶ BTW, I spent 24+ years in the Air Force working on aircraft‚Ä¶ Specifically heavy airframe maintenance. Trust me, airplane parts fail often. In fact most critical parts are changed at pre-programmed intervals before they have the chance to fail. It‚Äôs know as ‚ÄúTime change‚Äù‚Ä¶ Additionally, most airframes require about 8 man-hours of ground maintenance for every flying hour‚Ä¶ Some much more, so airplane analogies don‚Äôt usually work well‚Ä¶üòâ
data.author: Harold Huard

data.text: The Grade is a really nice riding bike. Very compliant. In fact if I were a very heavy rider I might think twice about it. I bought one for the Missus. She likes it very much. Watch the sizing though. She rides a 52cm and in the Grade she rides a 49cm.

data.text: yeah i'm around 180, and they have 55 in stock

data.text: Are you finding durability issues with carbon bikes in general, or for the GT Grade specifically? I‚Äôve heard nothing durability wise on the Grade, and if your inquiring about carbon bikes in general, if you take reasonable care of them they are just fine. When buying from a mainstream manufacturer like GT most are backed by a decent warranty and most even have some kind of a crash replacement policy üòâ
